net.proteusframework.core

Class StringFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.proteusframework.core.StringFactory

  • public class StringFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    The StringFactory class provides several methods to process strings
    Author:
    Yongjia Ni (yni@i2rd.com), Pat Double (double@i2rd.com)

      • convertToProgrammaticName2

        @Contract(value="null -> null; !null -> !null")
public static java.lang.String convertToProgrammaticName2(@Nullable java.lang.String pname)
        Converts a string into a programmatic name. This removes leading and trailing white space, then converts internal whitespace, hyphens, and periods to '_'. Then any non-alphanumeric characters are stripped. The result is a name with only letters, numbers, and underscores. The set of possible results is a subset of the possible results from convertToProgrammaticName.
        Parameters:
        pname - the name to convert. Can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        the parameter but in the new programmatic name format. Null if pname is null.

      • convertToUpperLower

        protected static @NonNull java.lang.String convertToUpperLower(java.lang.String s,
                                                               int offset,
                                                               int count,
                                                               boolean upper)
        Converts a range of characters in a string to upper or lower based on the selection of the upper boolean.
        Parameters:
        s - The string to convert.
        offset - The starting index for the conversion (0 based).
        count - The number of characters starting at the offset to convert.
        upper - True to make them uppercase, false to make them lowercase.
        Returns:
        The converted string.

      • createHttpQueryString

        public static @NonNull java.lang.String createHttpQueryString(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,?> params,
                                                              java.lang.String enc,
                                                              boolean encode)
                                                       throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException
        Create an HTTP query string from the Map.
        Parameters:
        params - the map.
        enc - the encoding.
        encode - true to encode, false otherwise.
        Returns:
        The query string.
        Throws:
        java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException - if the specified encoding is not supported.

      • escape

        @Contract(value="null,_,_->null;!null,_,_->!null")
public static @Nullable java.lang.String escape(java.lang.String str,
                                                                                                   java.lang.String esc,
                                                                                                   char c)
        Escapes characters in a string using a given escape character. The characters to be escaped will be prefixed by the escape character.
        Parameters:
        str - The String to escape
        esc - A set of characters that need to be escaped
        c - The escape character
        Returns:
        The escaped String

      • escapeForJavascript

        @Contract(value="null -> null; !null -> !null")
public static java.lang.String escapeForJavascript(java.lang.String str)
        Escapes a string for use as JavaScript data.
        Parameters:
        str - The string to escape.
        Returns:
        The escaped string.

      • escapeForSqlLikePattern

        @Contract(value="null->null;!null->!null")
public static @Nullable java.lang.String escapeForSqlLikePattern(java.lang.String pattern)
        Escapes a string so it can be used in a 'like' or 'ilike' query as the pattern without having any wildcards being present in the pattern. This is useful for constructing a pattern that you want to match exactly except for the addition of a prefix or postfix wildcards that you add after escaping. This can also be useful when using ilike to do a case-insensitive equality check.
        Parameters:
        pattern - The pattern. If this is null, then null will be returned.
        Returns:
        the escaped pattern, '_' and '%' will be escaped.

      • getXmlChars

        public static java.lang.String getXmlChars(java.lang.CharSequence orig)
        Get the characters in the specified string that are permitted by the XML 1.0 definition of a Char. The input must be a valid Unicode string (i.e. it may not contain the non-characters U+FFFE and U+FFFF and may not contain high surrogate codes with no low surrogate) from the Basic Multilingual Plane or Supplementary Multilingual Plane.

        Note that this only removes illegal characters. Characters that are merely discouraged are retained, and any characters that need to be encoded as entities are not modified.

        Parameters:
        orig - a valid Unicode string.
        Returns:
        the characters in the original string that are legal XML 1.0 text.

        the hash.

      • toList

        @Contract(value="null, _, _ -> !null")
public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> toList(java.lang.String str,
                                                                                             java.lang.String delim,
                                                                                             char escapeChar)
        This method is the compliment to toString(collection, delim, escapeChar). It splits a delimited String to a List, replacing any escaped delimiters with just the delimiter.
        Parameters:
        str - The String. If you pass in null you'll get an empty list.
        delim - The delimiter
        escapeChar - The escape character.
        Returns:
        A List containing elements from the split String. Never returns null

      • wordWrap

        @Contract(value="null,_,_,_->null;!null,_,_,_->!null")
public static @Nullable java.lang.String wordWrap(java.lang.String str,
                                                                                                         int lineLength,
                                                                                                         java.lang.String separator,
                                                                                                         java.util.Locale locale)
        Wrap a string to the desired line length. If the string is null or the string length is smaller than the desired lineLength, str will be returned. If str has separator in it, these separators will be preserved. If locale is null, default locale will be used.
        Parameters:
        str - the string to be wrapped
        lineLength - the desired line length
        separator - the line separator
        locale - the locale. if null, use default
        Returns:
        a new string with line separators inserted at proper location
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the desired lineLength is less than 1 or the separator is null or the lineLength is less than the longest word in the string.
